Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Successive Risk-Neutral Approximations of Dynamic Risk-Averse Optimization Problems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research aims at developing methods for solving stochastic dynamic optimization problems that involve risk-averse preferences. Mathematical models of risk aversion capture entire distributions of random outcomes with increased attention to events of small probability and high consequences. The project will concentrate on multistage stochastic optimization problems and on Markov decision processes incorporating dynamic risk measures and dynamic stochastic ordering constraints. The proposed numerical approach integrates modern theories of risk measures and stochastic orders with decomposition techniques for large-scale optimization problems, methods of non-smooth optimization, and stochastic control methods. The approach will be based on sequential risk-neutral approximations of risk-averse problems. The approximations will be used to devise primal and dual decomposition methods for multistage problems with dynamic risk measures and dynamic stochastic ordering constraints. Special attention will be paid to Markov decision problems. A theory of Markov risk measures and risk-averse dynamic programming will be developed. Numerical methods for risk-averse dynamic programming will also explore the idea of sequential risk-neutral approximations.

The project will provide qualitative advance in areas involving multi-stage decision-making in stochastic systems under high uncertainty and risk. It will provide modeling and algorithmic tools to formalize and solve long-term planning problems in which risk is an important issue and average performance criteria are insufficient. Problems of this nature arise in supply chain management, military planning problems, energy production and distribution, telecommunication, insurance and finance, medicine, and other areas. The project will benefit the graduate education at Rutgers University and Stevens Institute of Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project addresses stochastic dynamic optimization problems which involve risk-averse preferences. The main focus of this research has been on models involving constraints on events of small probability and high consequences, i.e., optimization problems with constraints on risk.

 

In this period, the research has been focused on risk-averse stochastic optimization problems with multivariate stochastic order constraints. The constraint requires that a random vector depending on our decisions stochastically dominates a given benchmark random vector. The multivariate order relations are applicable to multi-stage risk-averse optimization, where we look at a sequence of random cost or random profit. Furthermore, the decision making process naturally involves several performance measures, which are typically correlated. This necessitates the application of multivariate stochastic orders to control the distribution of the performance measures (costs, profits, or others).

 

We have analyzed suitable multivariate stochastic orders and characterized the linear stochastic dominance of second order in 7 different ways (using utility functions, the shortfall function, the integrated quantile function, or the conditional expectations.) The characterizations apply to the multivariate increasing convex order relation as well and are helpful for constructing risk-neutral approximate problems, amenable to decomposition.

 

We have proposed several numerical methods for solving optimization problems with multivariate dominance constraints. The methods construct a risk-neutral approximate model, verify whether its solution satisfies the necessary conditions for the original problem, and update the approximation appropriately. While the risk-neutral master problem can be solved with existing numerical methods, the verification of optimality of its solution represents theoretical and numerical challenge. it amounts to solving a a non-smooth and non-convex optimization problem. We have devised two methods for this purpose. They methods exploit the structure of the problem, some approaches of DC-optimization, and combinatorial techniques. We have provided sufficient conditions for the convergence of the methods. We have conducted extensive numerical experiments to explore numerically their efficiency and stability.

 

Additional question arising in this context is whether we can replace the multivariate relation by relations between the one-dimensional marginal distributions. Is it sufficient to control the distribution of each performance measure separately? In a dynamic setting, this amounts to the control of the cost/profit of each stage.  Our observation is that problems with univariate order constraints are easier to solve by our methods but the multivariate order is violated at the optimal solution in a substantial way.  

Two-stage problems allow us to determine decision, which will be implemented immediately but include a look-head period of time. The cost for the future operation of the system is required to be stochastically smaller than a benchmark cost distribution via the increasing convex order.
